title: Bloomberg Surveillance TV: July 15th, 2025 | Bloomberg Surveillance

rawLines.text: Bloomberg Audio Studios podcasts radio
news.
This is the Bloomberg Surveillance
Podcast. I'm Jonathan Pharaoh along with
Lisa Abramitz and Amarie Hordern. Join
us each day for insight from the best in
markets, economics, and geopolitics.
From our global headquarters in New York
City, we are live on Bloomberg
television weekday mornings from 6:00 to
9:00 a.m. Eastern. Subscribe to the
podcast on Apple, Spotify, or anywhere
else you listen. And as always, on the
Bloomberg terminal and the Bloomberg
business app, it's time for some calm.
Joining us now, the 79th Secretary of
the Treasury, Scesson. Mr. Secretary,
welcome to the program. Sir, let's pick
up on that theme. Not you calm in the
markets, but on inflation and where
rates should be. As Amarie pointed out,
we've had a string of softer than
expected inflation reads in this
country. We've had four. We might get
five at 8:30 Eastern time. Why do you
believe that's signal and not noise?
Well, I mean there there's some
persistence there, Jonathan. And look, I
I do have access to the the number the
night before, but when I'm coming on TV,
I don't look at it. So, I don't know
what the number is going to be at 8:30.
And I I wouldn't, you know, I I don't
know whether it's going to be down, up,
or flat, but I wouldn't put too much
emphasis on one number. I I think it's
the trend and I think one thing that
Wall Street, a lot of economists market
in general got wrong early on was that
tariffs were going to uh cause a
substantial price level rise which just
hasn't happened
and there are some people on the FOMC
the Federal Reserve still worried about
the prospect of that happening through
the summer. We've all sensed the
frustration from the White House across
the administration with Fed Chair Jay
Powell and a lot of confusion I think at
this point that maybe we can address in
this conversation. Is firing the Federal
Reserve chair under active consideration
in the White House, in the Treasury, in
your administration?
Uh, President Trump said numerous times
he's not going to fire Jay Powell. Uh,
you know, he's working the refs and you
I I've said before I'm a basketball fan.
There are two schools of working the
refs. There's the Bobby Knight school
and there's the the Dean Smith school.
President Trump uh seems to prefer the
Bobby Knight school. And I'll tell you,
I went back over the weekend and looked
and Bobby Knight won three NCAA
championships. My hero Dean Smith only
won two.
The NEC director Kevin Hasset, I'm not
sure what you'd call him, but he was
asked over the weekend, can the Fed
chair be fired? He said that's a thing
that's being looked into. How should we
understand those comments?
Uh, look, I I u and I will point out
Kevin was a collegiate basketball
player. Uh, and I I I think as President
Trump said, he he's not looking to fire
uh Chair Powell. And as I've said, I'm
not going to com I'm not going to
comment on future policy or future
mistakes the Fed will make. I'll only
comment on past mistakes. And look, they
they've had some big forecasting errors
and this may be one. Now,
is there a reason for not firing Kim?
And I asked that question because the
president's also said that his term is
about to expire in May of next year. Is
that the reason to ultimately just wait
or is it something else? Are you
convinced by the negative consequences
associated with such a move?
Look, I I I think a an independent
central bank is very important for the
conduct of monetary policy and we we can
see that in in terms of the both the
financial markets, the term premium and
longerterm debt.
You said previously the interview
process would begin later on in the
fall. There's been plenty of speculation
as to whether that process would be
brought forward. Mr. Secretary, do you
still, as far as you understand, believe
that's when the interview process to
replace the Fed chair will begin in the
fall, or is a formal process already
started?
Well, look, there there's a formal
process that's already starting. There
there are a lot of great candidates, and
you know, we we'll see how rapidly it
progresses. It's President Trump's
decision and it it will move at his
speed. Do you see any merit at all in
selecting maybe a candidate that's
already on the committee on the FOMC
versus taking a look at someone outside
of the Federal Reserve?
Again, there are a lot of good
candidates inside and outside the
Federal Reserve. Jonathan,
has the chairman himself, the Fed chair
Jake Pal given you any indication
whatsoever as to what he would do once
his term has expired? Will he vacate his
seat as the governor at the Federal
Reserve?
Well, tra traditionally, uh, the the Fed
chair also steps down as a governor, and
there's been a lot of talk of a shadow
Fed chair causing confusion in advance
uh, of his or her nomination, and I can
tell you, I think it'd be very confusing
for the market for a former Fed chair to
stay on. Also,
Mr. Treasury Secretary, I'd love to talk
to you about what's going on in Invidia
this morning. Jensen Wang, the CEO, out
in a blog statement saying that the
company has quote provided an update to
customers, noting that Nvidia is filing
applications to sell the H20 GPU again.
The US government has assured the
company that licenses will be granted
and Nvidia hopes to start deliveries
soon. Can you attest whether that's true
or not? The United States is willing to
let Nvidia sell H20s once again in
China? Well, again, I and Marie, I think
that'd be a judgment that the Chinese
indigenous uh manufacturers namely uh
Huawei and some others already have an
equivalent chip. So, you know, if
there's an equivalent chip, then the
Nvidia H20 could be sold cuz I I can
tell you uh the one thing that we do not
want is a digital uh belt and road uh
springing up around the world. because
other countries or China are
substituting for our American chip
manufacturers.
This is the same chip though that the
Trump administration blocked with export
controls in April. So why the change in
policy now?
Uh Emory, you you might say that that
was a negotiating uh chip that we used
in Geneva and in London. So this was
part of the trade talks when it comes to
Washington and Beijing.
Yes.
Was it a quidd proquo then? As you said
it wasn't, but was it potentially to
make sure that you can get the licenses
when it comes to rare earths?
Uh yeah, I think it it was all part of a
mosaic. Uh they had things we wanted, we
had things they wanted, and you know,
we're in a very good place. I expect to
meet my ch Chinese counterpart, the vice
premier, in the next few weeks. So, when
and where will that meeting take place?
We're we're still working on that. The
Chinese leadership has a big conclave at
the beginning of August. So, we're
trying to work out whether that could be
in a third country before or after that
conclave.
Will the administration release the
framework of the Geneva and London
talks?
Well, we we have released some of it and
you I'll I'll tell you that now having
settled on tariffs on the export
controls we can move on to the next
stage of talks and I think it's very
important both for the global economy
for the US economy and for the Chinese
economy for uh us to move on and talk
about China uh opening its markets and
the increase domestic and consumer
production there.
Are you hoping to get to that next phase
before August 12th when that's currently
the day taunt between these two
economies?
Yeah, I look I I think we're in a very
good place and I I tell market
participants not to worry about August
12th.
Should they worry about what's happening
with Europe with respect to the 30%
tariff rate? They don't seem to be
worrying, but I'm just curious whether
that's the final rate or whether the
letter was part of a negotiation that
Europe uh received from President Trump.
Uh well, Lisa, you know what I what I
would say is uh President Trump's able
to create a lot of leverage here. A lot
of leverage because he he's indifferent.
He's indifferent whether we take in the
30% rate or whether the Europeans come
to us with a much better deal. as I've
been saying for a while that if
countries or trading blocks don't come
with their best deals then the rates
could boomerang back. So, uh you
President Trump's leading this and what
I what I will tell you is that a lot of
the deals and this this is where he his
leadership's been invaluable. A lot of
the deals that I thought were excellent
deals keep getting improved upon every
time he takes up the maximum pressure
strategy. There is a theory in markets
and you don't even have to calm them.
They're pretty calm. They're watching
all of these rates and they're not
freaking out in parlance uh on Wall
Street. They're taking this in stride.
We're close to all-time highs, if not at
all-time highs. Do you see this is
giving a green light to Trump, to
President Trump, to keep going, to take
hardline approaches, and to keep trying
to get better and better deals?
Look, I I I think this this nar
narrative of this obsessive focus on the
market isn't right. President Trump
views this as a generational opportunity
to reset trade in a fair and sound
manner for the American people. So the
the idea that so some market ups or
downs are are going to be the deciding
factor here. what we uh are concerned
about and President Trump is laser
focused on is getting the best deals
because uh you we were not having fair
trade and now we're we're seeing with
these countries coming to the table the
quality of the deals gets better and
better. So we're not going to rush just
because of some market deadline. Now I
think what the market's seeing is
market's willing to look forward three,
six, 12 months and this is going to be
good for the US. It's going to be good
for the global economy.
If you do get some sort of signal from
the market though that this isn't going
to be good for the US economy. Is there
a trigger point? Is there sort of a
sense at which it it acts as a gut check
and sort of pulls back some of the
negotiating tactics?
Look, I I I think that the market
understands what we're doing. Sometimes
individual market people don't.
Sometimes the television personalities
don't. But you know, good good thing
about President Trump is he always tells
you what he wants and what he wants is
fair trade here.
I won't take that as a slight on me and
my colleagues around the table, Mr.
Treasury Secretary, but you did tell me
on April 2nd on Liberation Day that this
was the ceiling when it comes to those
rates. But since then, we have actually
had some tariff rates. the president
announced in letters higher than those
rates he announced on that big chart on
April 2nd. So is there no longer a
ceiling when it comes to tariff rates
when you are dealing with trading
partners?
Uh I I think that uh I I said if they if
they come and they negotiate in good
faith then those are ceilings and uh
some some of the talks got off to a very
slow start. So, who's negotiating good
faith at this moment? Who's not?
Again, I congratulated the UK the other
day, as I told many of our trading
partners and an Marie, I may have said
on that day or a few days after April
2nd. I'd advised countries to move
quickly because President Trump the
first deals are usually the best deals
and and the UK came in early. They got a
great deal and everybody else is kind of
dragging right now.
Well, when it comes to uh Japan, you're
headed there at the end of this week. Do
you expect to come back with a deal?
Uh I'm going to Japan to represent uh
the United States government and the
American people at the International
Expo, which we used to know as the
World's Fair. So this coming Saturday is
going to be America's day and I'll be
taking a delegation includes the labor
secretary, deputy secretary of state
will be representing the US. So th this
is a celebration of the US more than
trade talks.
Mr. Secretary, before you go, just a
final question. I'm embarrassed to say
that my knowledge of college basketball
is nothing like yours, but I can tell
you back in the '90s in English
football, there used to be a concept of
player managers. There used to be
certain managers of football teams that
also put themselves on the field and
they played too. Effectively, they had
two jobs. And I'm wondering from your
perspective whether that's something
you'd be interested in. We've seen that
throughout the administration. Is that
something you think that you could
pursue? Both the Treasury Secretary and
the Fed chair.
Uh look, I I I think I have the best job
in town. Uh I will do what President
Trump wants. We got a lot of great Fed
candidates and um you know I I'm
confident it's going to be a robust
process. Jonathan,
has he asked you?
What's that?
Has he asked you? Are you part of the
process?
Uh I I am part of the decision-making
process, but again, it's the final
decision is going to be President
Trump's.
Mr. Secretary, appreciate your time.
Thank you. The Treasury Secretary there,
Scott Besson, on a range of issues,
including trade and the future of this
Federal Reserve.
[Music]
Inflation data due at 8:30 Eastern time
about an hour away. Joining us now is
Sarah Hunt of Alpine Sang some words.
Sarah, good morning.
Good morning.
Is inflation dead?
I think it's quiet at the moment, but I
wouldn't I wouldn't completely rule it
out. I think that there's some
possibilities that it could pick its
head up, but I I think that it's hard
for people to anticipate data when we
spend a whole lot of time anticipating a
bunch of stuff that didn't happen. So, I
think there's a little bit of fatigue
there. So, it's hard to say right now.
It's difficult to forecast. There's
still some debate over the data we've
already had. What's underpinning these
softer than expected reads and why won't
it last? So if we think about whether or
not companies did pull a huge pull of
inventory forward and or people started
changing their behavior because they
knew what was coming, you could argue
why that's soft now and why it should
rise if the rates are going higher. But
you still see these moving of the
goalposts in terms of timing which
allows companies to bring inventories
back in again and refresh that. So I
could see a lot of bumpiness in the data
and I also think that companies have had
a lot of time to prepare for this and if
I'm sitting there I want my margins to
stay where they are. So I'm going to try
to do whatever substituting I can. So I
also think that there's probably a lack
of understanding how much of that
substitution has gone on and I think
that that is why it could be bumpier and
less dramatically higher than people are
expecting because they're expecting a
really fast move. I just wonder can we
expect immaculate disinflation ongoing
immaculate disinflation where there is
no pain in the overall economy at the
same time that inflation is dead. Does
that seem consistent with you or is
there kind of a tension right now
between employment data that's pretty
okay albeit with very slow activity and
inflation that seems to be maybe if not
dead in hospice.
It is one of those periods of time where
finding figuring out what that data
means is going to be tricky. It remains
tricky. Earnings are going to matter for
the stock market. Inflation's going to
matter to some degree but only if it's
really surprising or gets much higher
than people are looking for. And then
and then people start to investors
really start to worry. The question is
what do those trends look like? I mean
to Treasury Secretary Besson's point,
it's not just about one number. It's
about where the trend is going. If it
looks like the trend is reversing,
investors are going to like that a whole
lot less.
Do you just not pay attention to the
data at all and buy AI? Buy Nvidia and
just, you know, call it a day.
It would have been the good trade for
this year, right? I mean, that's that
that's sort of what happened is that you
had all this concern about AI going into
the beginning of the year. Then you had
the trade situation. Everybody started
looking at every single earnings call
from Microsoft or every hyperscaler to
parse exactly what their spending was
going to be. There was this little bit
of freakout and then everybody got over
it really quickly. So that would have
been that reversal and that goes back to
the idea that the companies that have
growth and the companies that generate a
ton of cash and have good margins are
the places that they end up performing
better than the rest of the market
anyway.
It would have been good to get in on
Nvidia just last night given the fact
that they have a blog post out saying
that those H20 chips that this
administration blocked are now going to
be able to go to China. How do you deal
with this basically flip-flop almost
within weeks or months of this
administration when you're trying to
direct what to do in a portfolio?
Well, I mean flip-flop is an interesting
term. I think it's more about I mean
again to Treasury Besson's point, it's
changing those dynamics may have been
part of that discussion all along. So
you have to assume that some of the
things that are coming out as X or Y,
maybe X or Y under certain
circumstances, but if I change my mind,
they're going to be different. So that's
got to be and I don't think that that's
entirely different from things that the
way the world works anyway. But I think
that certainly in the near term this
administration has been much different
about market changes than other
administrations.
It's not just Nvidia, it's AMD just
crossing resuming ship ship shipments to
China once their license clears that
stock is up in a pre-market as well.
Look, China's a big business for all of
these chip providers, and the key
question is, can they understand the
rules of the game enough to create chips
that are compliant with some of the
constraints that have been put on them
from the US government?
Sarah, it's good to see you. Sarah Hun
of Vampire Sax and Woods.
[Music]
I want to bring in Neil Data of
Renaissance Macro. Neil, welcome to the
program, sir. That's not four, it's
five. Why is that signal and not noise?
Well, I mean, I think look, we're
obviously tariff revenues are going up,
right? And the effective tariff rate is
rising. That was the case in June. And
despite that, inflation missed
expectations. So that means that I mean
tariffs increase costs. We all know
that. uh who ends up bearing the cost is
where the uh debate is. And you know, I
think at the margin, this probably
reflects more of a margin squeeze than
anything else. It's not like prices for
core goods aren't going up. They are. Um
but you have, you know, I mean, I was
just looking at the data. You see big
increases in appliances. You see big
increases in uh all sorts of household
um furnishing and supplies. Uh but it's
also important to remember that service
sector inflation uh service sector
prices represents the lion share of uh
of what people spend their money on and
prices in those areas continue to go
down. You know, ultimately it's going to
come down to nominal dollars spent,
right? Right. So to the extent that
people shift more of their household
budgets towards goods because the prices
of those things are going up um they'll
have less left over to spend elsewhere
and that means that services are at risk
and that's why they'll ultimately see
the prices for those things coming down.
So that to me seems to be what's going
on. Uh the nominal anchor isn't
changing. Tariffs are uh resulting in a
relative price shift. That's that's
pushing up um the prices for consumer
goods. That is clear. If you look at the
data, that's obvious. Look at just look
at household furnishings uh in the
latest uh report. Um but services are
are providing an important offset.
Neil, is that a good enough reason for
two Fed governors on the FOMC later on
this month to stick their hand up and
say, "I think we should cut rates."
Uh I I I mean, I don't think they'll be
as noisy about it uh in in July only
because um you know, the last employment
report gave them some calm, right?
because the unemployment rate went down.
But you know ultimately you know for me
it's about you know what is nominal
income uh doing when you take like the
sum product of jobs, hours and earnings
and you look at it over the last several
months it doesn't look particularly
encouraging. Uh at the same time you've
seen uh the work week decline
particularly in the areas that are
seeing the most robust jobs growth like
education and health. Right? So if you
start to see jobs in those areas slow
down uh what's left? Uh so um you know I
still continue to have like concerns
about the job market over the summer. Uh
but that just reinforces this weakness
in nominal income that we've seen. Uh so
ultimately you know it all comes down to
like the household budget constraint and
uh to the extent um that prices are
rising in one area that means that
quantity is going to go down in other
areas. So Neil, just to sort of sum up
what you've been talking about, I think
it's really interesting that you see
these numbers as not representing
strength in the economy, but a sign of
weakness in places like services that is
bringing down the overall inflation rate
that otherwise is getting inflated by
certain goods prices going up uh like
home appliances. At what point is that
weakness necessary to keep inflation
low? In other words, not necessarily a
reason for the Fed to cut, but to hold
where they are so that you can have that
offset in a way that doesn't allow
inflation to really kick back up.
I mean, I don't think one rate cut's
really going to change that in any in
any material way. I mean, the Fed Fed
policy is still restrictive.
That means they can they can start and
they'd still be restrictive. It doesn't
they don't have to promise like a a
broad swath of of rate cuts. In fact,
they're not doing that. So um you know I
don't think a rate cut in July or even
one in September is going to materially
u you know change that dynamic.
If you are just joining us welcome to
the program. Equities higher here. The
opening bell about 54 minutes away.
Moments ago inflation data in the United
States month over month headline CPI up
from 0.1% the previous month to 0.3 in
line with expectations. But for core CPI
it's another downside surprise. 0.2%
against an expectation of 0.3. It's five
consecutive months of softer than
expected core CPI. Mike McKe's back with
us for more. Mike, you've had a second
look. What jumps out to you?
Well, I think Neil pointed out the major
tariff implications here. We do see a
4/10% rise in apparel overall and a
significant rise in footwear up 7/10en
of a percent. Uh male footwear in
particular. Now, those things come from
China. other things uh coming from China
that uh go up or from other Asian
countries. Furniture as he mentioned was
up 4/10en of a percent. Household
furnishings up 1% and appliances up
1.9%. They were up 8/10en of a percent
last month. Uh a lot of this probably
has to do with the tariffs on steel. We
saw that when uh we had the steel
tariffs in the first Trump
administration that appliance prices
went up. Uh food 3/10en of 8% still in
line. Uh president added extra tariffs
on tomatoes yesterday but in June they
were down one and a half% and I know
Amarie is anxious to know that eggs were
down 7.4%.
Uh one other thing that comes in uh for
uh the China aspect of it is toy prices
So we are seeing some tariff pass
through here. But again uh I would look
at what Neil was saying about service
prices. they were relatively restrained
up 3/10en of 8%. Uh we saw medical care
and uh auto insurance prices very tame
this month. So some of the things that
we had seen pushing up inflation in the
services categories have backed off for
a while at least. Mike McKe, thank you
sir. Equities higher in response to some
of this. We're up by 4/10en of 1% on the
S&P. Yields a little bit lower across
the bond market. The yield curve looks
like this. 10ear yields this morning
down by two basis points. Similar move
on a 30. So you don't see the tariff
inflation on a headline, but you start
to see it just a little bit beneath the
surface
and you start to see what the response
function is of households that they
might be cutting back maybe on eating
out to compensate for the increased
costs elsewhere which uh you wonder on a
compositional level whether this tamps
down overall inflation even as you see
pockets of higher prices in select
areas. Is that the path of travel or is
that just the current state of affairs
as people take stock of exactly what the
new scenario is? We can have that
discussion right now with David Kelly of
JP Morgan Asset Management. David,
welcome to the program, sir. How much
comfort can you take from this morning's
inflation data?
Not a lot. Uh it's a very interesting
report because you can see sort of the
fading of issues that were causing
inflation over the last few years, but
you can also see the beginnings of the
inflation problem related to tariffs. Uh
so if you look at owner's equivalent
rent, auto insurance, those are the
things that really held inflation up and
they're going away. And the other thing
that really helped this report is we had
a further decline in airline fairs, a
further decline in lodging prices.
There's a lot of weakness in the tourism
industry right now and that's in this
report. But uh when you look at core
goods outside of new autos, we're seeing
those goods prices go up and that's
where you're going to see this tariff
inflation. And we have only seen the
thin end of the wedge here. It takes a
while for the tariffs to get to be
implemented. Takes a while for the
revenue to be collected. Takes a while
for the the inventory to make it to
people's shelves. takes a while for the
retailers to say, "Look, I'm going to
have to mark it up, but it is coming.
Um, so, you know, I fully agree with the
Fed's forecast that inflation's going to
go up between now and the end of the
year, and they've got to stay on their
guard."
And yet, David, they also believe it
starts to come back down again. In fact,
for that reason, some officials,
including Governor Waller, believes you
can look through it. Do you think you
can just look through it?
Not Not yet. Because we also have a lot
of fiscal sugar in the first half of
next year. Uh what's going to happen is
that we had a lot of temporary tax
breaks put in for four years, but they
start at the start of this year. They're
not going to adjust income tax
withholding schedules quickly enough.
That means a bumper season for refunds
early next year. And you know, we know
from 2022 that you got supply chain
issues and then you give consumers a lot
of extra cash. What happens? You end up
with inflation. I mean, eventually I
think it'll fade in the long run. I am
not an inflation hawk in America. I
think inflation will fade, but I think
it's going to be sustained by some of
the provisions of the OBBBA. Uh and and
I because of that, I think the Fed needs
to hold off here. If we got clarity on
tariffs, if we could say this is what
the tariffs rule are and they will go no
higher, then I think that makes it
easier for the Fed. So, you know, I
think the administration really needs to
think about, look, could we please
whatever the tariff policy is, let's
make it and be done with it because this
uncertainty is the very thing that's
making it impossible for the Federal
Reserve to say that that we're out of
the woods or will be out of the woods on
inflation.
David, is there a sort of a necessary
weakness that we need to see in consumer
spending and services at this point to
make sure that inflation doesn't take
off? In other words, that pain that Neil
was talking about that you could start
seeing uh on the in the data on the
margins.
Well, that's a tough way to do it. I
mean, the way you you want to if you're
worried about a long-term inflation
problem, it's only going to be come
because wage growth sort of compensate
for price increases. Now, we still have
a relatively weak labor force in terms
of their ability to demand wage
increases. Uh, you know, I think again
we have to think a little bit about how
immigration is affecting labor supply.
And again, there's huge question marks
there. But so long as we don't see an
acceleration in wage growth, the
inflation will fade. You It's not just a
matter of consumer spending being weak.
Um, so long as wage growth is
controlled, inflation will fade again.
But I think it's way too early to say
that uh, you know, inflation is coming
down to 2%, we still got to get past
tariffs, we've got to get past the
stimulative effects of this fiscal bill,
and that's really what's causing the
delay in any further Fed easing.
Neil Data of Renmax still with us. Neil,
today's about prices, Thursday's about
spending. Let's talk about retail sales.
How do you expect some of our
understanding of prices this morning to
show up in spending and retail sales
later this week?
Well, I mean, if goods prices are rising
and the consensus expects nominal
nominal retail sales to rise 3/10, that
basically tells you that real spending
on goods is declining. That's not
exactly an encouraging situation. So um
you know I mean the fact that price
increases are showing up um and you know
it's more or less matching what you see
in the retail sales data um that
basically tells you that the volume of
goods sold is going down. Look it comes
back to P * Q. Whatever um you know
whatever goes into price is going to
come out of quantity because the nominal
anchor hasn't really changed. Uh so you
know look I mean I think consumers are
actually quite resistant to higher
prices uh with the exception of the uh
University of Michigan data. Um if you
look at you know other estimates for
inflation expectations was whe whether
that's the the New York Fed survey of
consumer expectations, Atlanta Fed
business inflation expectations,
professional forecasters inflation
expectations. Um it suggests that you
know people are resistant to higher
prices and they're acting as if you know
if you look at the areas where people
have been cutting back their consumption
those are the areas where the prices
have been going up the most. So it's not
particularly surprising. Um and the
labor markets remain still in a tricky
spot. Um you know while the unemployment
rate remains low uh you still have you
know rising increase in you know
discouraged workers. You know people
that are out of the workforce but want a
job now. um you know companies are
telling you like the small businesses
are saying that there's uh you know poor
sales uh a bigger concern. So you know I
I think that that probably reinforces
ongoing weakness in uh in wage growth
and you know that means that households
don't really have the capacity to absorb
um higher prices and that means to cut
back. No, and it's a good point, Neil.
And David, I guess that if you take what
Neil is saying, the idea that you do see
real price resistance by consumers, and
if you do see this sort of compensating
for the extra expense in goods by
pulling back on services, what would the
harm be for the Fed to cut rates by just
25 basis points or 50 basis points?
Well, the any, you know, any problems
the economy is facing is not really
about interest rates being too high. And
I think that I think, you know, I think
we have to think carefully about
long-term policies about helping the
labor force grow, uh, about helping free
enterprise and reduce regulation and
reduce barriers to to business and and,
you know, I think we need to focus on
that. Um, I don't think the interest
rates are too high right now. I think
the Fed's the steward of the dollar and
of our inflation outlook in the long
run. And they've said they're committed
to 2% inflation. I think they should
stick to their guns. Um, and you know,
if the economy gets into trouble, it's
not because they kept rates too high.
Neil, I just want to give you the final
word just on housing, which is something
you've been following now for months and
months and months and flagging the
weakness here. Why is that so important
to you, Neil?
Well, because it undercuts an argument
that was just made, which is that, you
know, that interest rates are fine,
right? I mean, obviously housing isn't
weakening because of tariffs or anything
else. Housing's weakening because rates
are too high and you're seeing um you
know a rising pile of completed new
unsold inventory. I mean that hasn't
been as high uh that's that's been
rising um you know over the last year or
so and that's starting to weigh on home
prices which we see. So you know I I
think that the housing market does
provide some evidence that interest
rates are restraining economic activity.
Is that the Fed's fault or is that the
fault of Congress, Neil?
So no, but the reason the reason we're
seeing that sorry the re reason uh the
reason we're have got trouble in the
housing market is not because rates are
too high now. It's because rates were
way too low for way too long after the
great financial crisis causing prices to
jack up to a level that cannot be
supported at normal mortgage rates.
There's nothing wrong with mortgage
rates. The problem is home prices which
are too high because rates were too low
for too long.
Well, mortgage rates are running 6 and
12 to 7% and wage growth is rising just
3%. So, I think the math is actually
getting quite challenging for most
people. That's why housing is not
working.
Well, it's challenging, but only because
home prices are the anomaly here.
They're just too high because rates were
too low for too long.
I'm sitting back now, Jent. I thought
you'd continue. Neil D of Remma, David
Kelly at JP Morgan. So, the two of you
appreciate it. Thank you.
This is the Bloomberg Surveillance
Podcast, bringing you the best in
markets, economics, and geopolitics. You
can watch the show live on Bloomberg TV
weekday mornings from 6:00 a.m. to 9:00
a.m. Eastern. Subscribe to the podcast
on Apple, Spotify, or anywhere else you
listen. And as always, on the Bloomberg
Terminal and the Bloomberg Business App.
[Music]

cleanText:
Bloomberg Audio Studios podcasts radio news.

This is the Bloomberg Surveillance Podcast.
I'm Jonathan Pharaoh along with Lisa Abramitz and Amarie Hordern.
Join us each day for insight from the best in markets, economics, and geopolitics.
From our global headquarters in New York City, we are live on Bloomberg television weekday mornings from 6:00 to 9:00 a.m. Eastern.
Subscribe to the podcast on Apple, Spotify, or anywhere else you listen.
And as always, on the Bloomberg terminal and the Bloomberg business app, it's time for some calm.

Joining us now, the 79th Secretary of the Treasury, Scott Bessent.
Mr. Secretary, welcome to the program.
Sir, let's pick up on that theme.
Not you calm in the markets, but on inflation and where rates should be.
As Amarie pointed out, we've had a string of softer than expected inflation reads in this country.
We've had four.
We might get five at 8:30 Eastern time.
Why do you believe that's signal and not noise?

Well, I mean there there's some persistence there, Jonathan.
And look, I do have access to the number the night before, but when I'm coming on TV, I don't look at it.
So, I don't know what the number is going to be at 8:30.
And I I wouldn't, you know, I I don't know whether it's going to be down, up, or flat, but I wouldn't put too much emphasis on one number.
I I think it's the trend and I think one thing that Wall Street, a lot of economists market in general got wrong early on was that tariffs were going to uh cause a substantial price level rise which just hasn't happened and there are some people on the FOMC the Federal Reserve still worried about the prospect of that happening through the summer.
We've all sensed the frustration from the White House across the administration with Fed Chair Jay Powell and a lot of confusion I think at this point that maybe we can address in this conversation.
Is firing the Federal Reserve chair under active consideration in the White House, in the Treasury, in your administration?

Uh, President Trump said numerous times he's not going to fire Jay Powell.
Uh, you know, he's working the refs and you I I've said before I'm a basketball fan.
There are two schools of working the refs.
There's the Bobby Knight school and there's the the Dean Smith school.
President Trump uh seems to prefer the Bobby Knight school.
And I'll tell you, I went back over the weekend and looked and Bobby Knight won three NCAA championships.
My hero Dean Smith only won two.

The NEC director Kevin Hasset, I'm not sure what you'd call him, but he was asked over the weekend, can the Fed chair be fired?
He said that's a thing that's being looked into.
How should we understand those comments?

Uh, look, I I u and I will point out Kevin was a collegiate basketball player.
Uh, and I I I think as President Trump said, he he's not looking to fire uh Chair Powell.
And as I've said, I'm not going to comment on future policy or future mistakes the Fed will make.
I'll only comment on past mistakes.
And look, they they've had some big forecasting errors and this may be one.
Now, is there a reason for not firing Kim?
And I asked that question because the president's also said that his term is about to expire in May of next year.
Is that the reason to ultimately just wait or is it something else?
Are you convinced by the negative consequences associated with such a move?

Look, I I I think a an independent central bank is very important for the conduct of monetary policy and we we can see that in in terms of the both the financial markets, the term premium and longerterm debt.

You said previously the interview process would begin later on in the fall.
There's been plenty of speculation as to whether that process would be brought forward.
Mr. Secretary, do you still, as far as you understand, believe that's when the interview process to replace the Fed chair will begin in the fall, or is a formal process already started?

Well, look, there there's a formal process that's already starting.
There there are a lot of great candidates, and you know, we we'll see how rapidly it progresses.
It's President Trump's decision and it it will move at his speed.
Do you see any merit at all in selecting maybe a candidate that's already on the committee on the FOMC versus taking a look at someone outside of the Federal Reserve?

Again, there are a lot of good candidates inside and outside the Federal Reserve.
Jonathan, has the chairman himself, the Fed chair Jake Pal given you any indication whatsoever as to what he would do once his term has expired?
Will he vacate his seat as the governor at the Federal Reserve?

Well, tra traditionally, uh, the the Fed chair also steps down as a governor, and there's been a lot of talk of a shadow Fed chair causing confusion in advance uh, of his or her nomination, and I can tell you, I think it'd be very confusing for the market for a former Fed chair to stay on.
Also, Mr. Treasury Secretary, I'd love to talk to you about what's going on in Invidia this morning.
Jensen Wang, the CEO, out in a blog statement saying that the company has quote provided an update to customers, noting that Nvidia is filing applications to sell the H20 GPU again.
The US government has assured the company that licenses will be granted and Nvidia hopes to start deliveries soon.
Can you attest whether that's true or not?
The United States is willing to let Nvidia sell H20s once again in China?

Well, again, I and Marie, I think that'd be a judgment that the Chinese indigenous uh manufacturers namely uh Huawei and some others already have an equivalent chip.
So, you know, if there's an equivalent chip, then the Nvidia H20 could be sold cuz I I can tell you uh the one thing that we do not want is a digital uh belt and road uh springing up around the world.
because other countries or China are substituting for our American chip manufacturers.

This is the same chip though that the Trump administration blocked with export controls in April.
So why the change in policy now?

Uh Emory, you you might say that that was a negotiating uh chip that we used in Geneva and in London.
So this was part of the trade talks when it comes to Washington and Beijing.

Yes.

Was it a quidd pro quo then?
As you said it wasn't, but was it potentially to make sure that you can get the licenses when it comes to rare earths?

Uh yeah, I think it it was all part of a mosaic.
Uh they had things we wanted, we had things they wanted, and you know, we're in a very good place.
I expect to meet my Chinese counterpart, the vice premier, in the next few weeks.
So, when and where will that meeting take place?

We're we're still working on that.
The Chinese leadership has a big conclave at the beginning of August.
So, we're trying to work out whether that could be in a third country before or after that conclave.

Will the administration release the framework of the Geneva and London talks?

Well, we we have released some of it and you I'll I'll tell you that now having settled on tariffs on the export controls we can move on to the next stage of talks and I think it's very important both for the global economy for the US economy and for the Chinese economy for uh us to move on and talk about China uh opening its markets and the increase domestic and consumer production there.

Are you hoping to get to that next phase before August 12th when that's currently the day taunt between these two economies?

Yeah, I look I I think we're in a very good place and I I tell market participants not to worry about August 12th.

Should they worry about what's happening with Europe with respect to the 30% tariff rate?
They don't seem to be worrying, but I'm just curious whether that's the final rate or whether the letter was part of a negotiation that Europe uh received from President Trump.

Uh well, Lisa, you know what I what I would say is uh President Trump's able to create a lot of leverage here.
A lot of leverage because he he's indifferent.
He's indifferent whether we take in the 30% rate or whether the Europeans come to us with a much better deal.
as I've been saying for a while that if countries or trading blocks don't come with their best deals then the rates could boomerang back.
So, uh you President Trump's leading this and what I what I will tell you is that a lot of the deals and this this is where he his leadership's been invaluable.
A lot of the deals that I thought were excellent deals keep getting improved upon every time he takes up the maximum pressure strategy.
There is a theory in markets and you don't even have to calm them.
They're pretty calm.
They're watching all of these rates and they're not freaking out in parlance uh on Wall Street.
They're taking this in stride.
We're close to all-time highs, if not at all-time highs.
Do you see this is giving a green light to Trump, to President Trump, to keep going, to take hardline approaches, and to keep trying to get better and better deals?

Look, I I I think this this narrative of this obsessive focus on the market isn't right.
President Trump views this as a generational opportunity to reset trade in a fair and sound manner for the American people.
So the the idea that so some market ups or downs are are going to be the deciding factor here.
what we uh are concerned about and President Trump is laser focused on is getting the best deals because uh you we were not having fair trade and now we're we're seeing with these countries coming to the table the quality of the deals gets better and better.
So we're not going to rush just because of some market deadline.
Now I think what the market's seeing is market's willing to look forward three, six, 12 months and this is going to be good for the US.
It's going to be good for the global economy.

If you do get some sort of signal from the market though that this isn't going to be good for the US economy.
Is there a trigger point?
Is there sort of a sense at which it it acts as a gut check and sort of pulls back some of the negotiating tactics?

Look, I I I think that the market understands what we're doing.
Sometimes individual market people don't.
Sometimes the television personalities don't.
But you know, good good thing about President Trump is he always tells you what he wants and what he wants is fair trade here.

I won't take that as a slight on me and my colleagues around the table, Mr. Treasury Secretary, but you did tell me on April 2nd on Liberation Day that this was the ceiling when it comes to those rates.
But since then, we have actually had some tariff rates.
the president announced in letters higher than those rates he announced on that big chart on April 2nd.
So is there no longer a ceiling when it comes to tariff rates when you are dealing with trading partners?

Uh I I think that uh I I said if they if they come and they negotiate in good faith then those are ceilings and uh some some of the talks got off to a very slow start.
So, who's negotiating good faith at this moment?
Who's not?

Again, I congratulated the UK the other day, as I told many of our trading partners and an Marie, I may have said on that day or a few days after April 2nd.
I'd advised countries to move quickly because President Trump the first deals are usually the best deals and and the UK came in early.
They got a great deal and everybody else is kind of dragging right now.

Well, when it comes to uh Japan, you're headed there at the end of this week.
Do you expect to come back with a deal?

Uh I'm going to Japan to represent uh the United States government and the American people at the International Expo, which we used to know as the World's Fair.
So this coming Saturday is going to be America's day and I'll be taking a delegation includes the labor secretary, deputy secretary of state will be representing the US.
So th this is a celebration of the US more than trade talks.

Mr. Secretary, before you go, just a final question.
I'm embarrassed to say that my knowledge of college basketball is nothing like yours, but I can tell you back in the '90s in English football, there used to be a concept of player managers.
There used to be certain managers of football teams that also put themselves on the field and they played too.
Effectively, they had two jobs.
And I'm wondering from your perspective whether that's something you'd be interested in.
We've seen that throughout the administration.
Is that something you think that you could pursue?
Both the Treasury Secretary and the Fed chair.

Uh look, I I I think I have the best job in town.
Uh I will do what President Trump wants.
We got a lot of great Fed candidates and um you know I I'm confident it's going to be a robust process.
Jonathan, has he asked you?

What's that?

Has he asked you?
Are you part of the process?

Uh I I am part of the decision-making process, but again, it's the final decision is going to be President Trump's.

Mr. Secretary, appreciate your time.
Thank you.
The Treasury Secretary there, Scott Bessent, on a range of issues, including trade and the future of this Federal Reserve.

[Music]

Inflation data due at 8:30 Eastern time about an hour away.
Joining us now is Sarah Hunt of Alpine Saxon Woods.
Sarah, good morning.

Good morning.

Is inflation dead?

I think it's quiet at the moment, but I wouldn't I wouldn't completely rule it out.
I think that there's some possibilities that it could pick its head up, but I I think that it's hard for people to anticipate data when we spend a whole lot of time anticipating a bunch of stuff that didn't happen.
So, I think there's a little bit of fatigue there.
So, it's hard to say right now.
It's difficult to forecast.
There's still some debate over the data we've already had.
What's underpinning these softer than expected reads and why won't it last?
So if we think about whether or not companies did pull a huge pull of inventory forward and or people started changing their behavior because they knew what was coming, you could argue why that's soft now and why it should rise if the rates are going higher.
But you still see these moving of the goalposts in terms of timing which allows companies to bring inventories back in again and refresh that.
So I could see a lot of bumpiness in the data and I also think that companies have had a lot of time to prepare for this and if I'm sitting there I want my margins to stay where they are.
So I'm going to try to do whatever substituting I can.
So I also think that there's probably a lack of understanding how much of that substitution has gone on and I think that that


is why it could be bumpier and less dramatically higher than people are expecting because they're expecting a really fast move.
I just wonder, can we expect immaculate disinflation, ongoing immaculate disinflation, where there is no pain in the overall economy at the same time that inflation is dead?
Does that seem consistent with you, or is there kind of a tension right now between employment data that's pretty okay, albeit with very slow activity, and inflation that seems to be maybe, if not dead, in hospice?
It is one of those periods of time where finding, figuring out what that data means is going to be tricky.
It remains tricky.
Earnings are going to matter for the stock market.
Inflation's going to matter to some degree, but only if it's really surprising or gets much higher than people are looking for.
And then, and then people start to, investors really start to worry.
The question is, what do those trends look like?
I mean, to US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent's point, it's not just about one number.
It's about where the trend is going.
If it looks like the trend is reversing, investors are going to like that a whole lot less.
Do you just not pay attention to the data at all and buy AI?
Buy Nvidia and just, you know, call it a day.
It would have been the good trade for this year, right?
I mean, that's that, that's sort of what happened is that you had all this concern about AI going into the beginning of the year.
Then you had the trade situation.
Everybody started looking at every single earnings call from Microsoft or every hyperscaler to parse exactly what their spending was going to be.
There was this little bit of freakout, and then everybody got over it really quickly.
So that would have been that reversal, and that goes back to the idea that the companies that have growth and the companies that generate a ton of cash and have good margins are the places that they end up performing better than the rest of the market anyway.
It would have been good to get in on Nvidia just last night, given the fact that they have a blog post out saying that those H20 chips that this administration blocked are now going to be able to go to China.
How do you deal with this basically flip-flop almost within weeks or months of this administration when you're trying to direct what to do in a portfolio?
Well, I mean, flip-flop is an interesting term.
I think it's more about, I mean, again, to US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent's point, it's changing those dynamics may have been part of that discussion all along.
So you have to assume that some of the things that are coming out as X or Y, maybe X or Y under certain circumstances, but if I change my mind, they're going to be different.
So that's got to be, and I don't think that that's entirely different from things that the way the world works anyway.
But I think that certainly in the near term, this administration has been much different about market changes than other administrations.
It's not just Nvidia, it's AMD just crossing, resuming ship, ship shipments to China once their license clears, that stock is up in a pre-market as well.
Look, China's a big business for all of these chip providers, and the key question is, can they understand the rules of the game enough to create chips that are compliant with some of the constraints that have been put on them from the US government?
Sarah, it's good to see you.
Sarah Hunt of Alpine Saxon Woods.
[Music]
I want to bring in Neil Dutta of Renaissance Macro.
Neil, welcome to the program, sir.
That's not four, it's five.
Why is that signal and not noise?
Well, I mean, I think, look, we're obviously tariff revenues are going up, right?
And the effective tariff rate is rising.
That was the case in June.
And despite that, inflation missed expectations.
So that means that, I mean, tariffs increase costs.
We all know that.
Uh, who ends up bearing the cost is where the uh debate is.
And you know, I think at the margin, this probably reflects more of a margin squeeze than anything else.
It's not like prices for core goods aren't going up.
They are.
Um, but you have, you know, I mean, I was just looking at the data.
You see big increases in appliances.
You see big increases in uh all sorts of household um furnishing and supplies.
Uh, but it's also important to remember that service sector inflation, uh, service sector prices represents the lion share of uh of what people spend their money on, and prices in those areas continue to go down.
You know, ultimately it's going to come down to nominal dollars spent, right?
Right.
So to the extent that people shift more of their household budgets towards goods because the prices of those things are going up, um, they'll have less left over to spend elsewhere, and that means that services are at risk, and that's why they'll ultimately see the prices for those things coming down.
So that to me seems to be what's going on.
Uh, the nominal anchor isn't changing.
Tariffs are uh resulting in a relative price shift.
That's that's pushing up um the prices for consumer goods.
That is clear.
If you look at the data, that's obvious.
Look at just look at household furnishings uh in the latest uh report.
Um, but services are are providing an important offset.
Neil, is that a good enough reason for two Fed governors on the FOMC later on this month to stick their hand up and say, "I think we should cut rates."
Uh, I, I, I mean, I don't think they'll be as noisy about it uh in in July only because um, you know, the last employment report gave them some calm, right?
Because the unemployment rate went down.
But you know, ultimately, you know, for me, it's about, you know, what is nominal income uh doing when you take like the sum product of jobs, hours, and earnings, and you look at it over the last several months, it doesn't look particularly encouraging.
Uh, at the same time, you've seen uh the work week decline, particularly in the areas that are seeing the most robust jobs growth, like education and health.
Right?
So if you start to see jobs in those areas slow down, uh what's left?
Uh, so um, you know, I still continue to have like concerns about the job market over the summer.
Uh, but that just reinforces this weakness in nominal income that we've seen.
Uh, so ultimately, you know, it all comes down to like the household budget constraint, and uh to the extent um that prices are rising in one area, that means that quantity is going to go down in other areas.
So Neil, just to sort of sum up what you've been talking about, I think it's really interesting that you see these numbers as not representing strength in the economy, but a sign of weakness in places like services that is bringing down the overall inflation rate that otherwise is getting inflated by certain goods prices going up, uh, like home appliances.
At what point is that weakness necessary to keep inflation low?
In other words, not necessarily a reason for the Fed to cut, but to hold where they are so that you can have that offset in a way that doesn't allow inflation to really kick back up.
I mean, I don't think one rate cut's really going to change that in any in any material way.
I mean, the Fed, Fed policy is still restrictive.
That means they can, they can start, and they'd still be restrictive.
It doesn't, they don't have to promise like a a broad swath of of rate cuts.
In fact, they're not doing that.
So um, you know, I don't think a rate cut in July or even one in September is going to materially u, you know, change that dynamic.
If you are just joining us, welcome to the program.
Equities higher here.
The opening bell about 54 minutes away.
Moments ago, inflation data in the United States, month over month, headline CPI up from 0.1% the previous month to 0.3, in line with expectations.
But for core CPI, it's another downside surprise, 0.2% against an expectation of 0.3.
It's five consecutive months of softer than expected core CPI.
Mike McKe's back with us for more.
Mike, you've had a second look.
What jumps out to you?
Well, I think Neil pointed out the major tariff implications here.
We do see a 4/10% rise in apparel overall and a significant rise in footwear, up 7/10 of a percent.
Uh, male footwear in particular.
Now, those things come from China.
Other things uh coming from China that uh go up or from other Asian countries.
Furniture, as he mentioned, was up 4/10 of a percent.
Household furnishings up 1% and appliances up 1.9%.
They were up 8/10 of a percent last month.
Uh, a lot of this probably has to do with the tariffs on steel.
We saw that when uh we had the steel tariffs in the first President Trump administration that appliance prices went up.
Uh, food 3/10 of 8% still in line.
Uh, President Trump added extra tariffs on tomatoes yesterday, but in June they were down one and a half%, and I know Amarie is anxious to know that eggs were down 7.4%.
Uh, one other thing that comes in uh for uh the China aspect of it is toy prices up 1.8%.
So we are seeing some tariff pass through here.
But again, uh, I would look at what Neil was saying about service prices.
They were relatively restrained, up 3/10 of 8%.
Uh, we saw medical care and uh auto insurance prices very tame this month.
So some of the things that we had seen pushing up inflation in the services categories have backed off for a while at least.
Mike McKe, thank you, sir.
Equities higher in response to some of this.
We're up by 4/10 of 1% on the S&P.
Yields a little bit lower across the bond market.
The yield curve looks like this.
10-year yields this morning down by two basis points.
Similar move on a 30.
So you don't see the tariff inflation on a headline, but you start to see it just a little bit beneath the surface, and you start to see what the response function is of households that they might be cutting back maybe on eating out to compensate for the increased costs elsewhere, which uh you wonder on a compositional level whether this tamps down overall inflation, even as you see pockets of higher prices in select areas.
Is that the path of travel, or is that just the current state of affairs as people take stock of exactly what the new scenario is?
We can have that discussion right now with David Kelly of JPMorgan Asset Management.
David, welcome to the program, sir.
How much comfort can you take from this morning's inflation data?
Not a lot.
Uh, it's a very interesting report because you can see sort of the fading of issues that were causing inflation over the last few years, but you can also see the beginnings of the inflation problem related to tariffs.
Uh, so if you look at owner's equivalent rent, auto insurance, those are the things that really held inflation up, and they're going away.
And the other thing that really helped this report is we had a further decline in airline fairs, a further decline in lodging prices.
There's a lot of weakness in the tourism industry right now, and that's in this report.
But uh when you look at core goods outside of new autos, we're seeing those goods prices go up, and that's where you're going to see this tariff inflation.
And we have only seen the thin end of the wedge here.
It takes a while for the tariffs to get to be implemented.
Takes a while for the revenue to be collected.
Takes a while for the the inventory to make it to people's shelves.
Takes a while for the retailers to say, "Look, I'm going to have to mark it up, but it is coming.
Um, so, you know, I fully agree with the Fed's forecast that inflation's going to go up between now and the end of the year, and they've got to stay on their guard."
And yet, David, they also believe it starts to come back down again.
In fact, for that reason, some officials, including Governor Waller, believes you can look through it.
Do you think you can just look through it?
Not yet.
Because we also have a lot of fiscal sugar in the first half of next year.
Uh, what's going to happen is that we had a lot of temporary tax breaks put in for four years, but they start at the start of this year.
They're not going to adjust income tax withholding schedules quickly enough.
That means a bumper season for refunds early next year.
And you know, we know from 2022 that you got supply chain issues, and then you give consumers a lot of extra cash.
What happens?
You end up with inflation.
I mean, eventually I think it'll fade in the long run.
I am not an inflation hawk in America.
I think inflation will fade, but I think it's going to be sustained by some of the provisions of the OBBBA.
Uh, and and I, because of that, I think the Fed needs to hold off here.
If we got clarity on tariffs, if we could say this is what the tariffs rule are, and they will go no higher, then I think that makes it easier for the Fed.
So, you know, I think the administration really needs to think about, look, could we please, whatever the tariff policy is, let's make it and be done with it because this uncertainty is the very thing that's making it impossible for the Federal Reserve to say that that we're out of the woods or will be out of the woods on inflation.
David, is there a sort of a necessary weakness that we need to see in consumer spending and services at this point to make sure that inflation doesn't take off?
In other words, that pain that Neil was talking about that you could start seeing uh on the in the data on the margins.
Well, that's a tough way to do it.
I mean, the way you, you want to, if you're worried about a long-term inflation problem, it's only going to be come because wage growth sort of compensate for price increases.
Now, we still have a relatively weak labor force in terms of their ability to demand wage increases.
Uh, you know, I think again, we have to think a little bit about how immigration is affecting labor supply.
And again, there's huge question marks there.
But so long as we don't see an acceleration in wage growth, the inflation will fade.
You, it's not just a matter of consumer spending being weak.
Um, so long as wage growth is controlled, inflation will fade again.
But I think it's way too early to say that uh, you know, inflation is coming down to 2%, we still got to get past tariffs, we've got to get past the stimulative effects of this fiscal bill, and that's really what's causing the delay in any further Fed easing.
Neil Data of Renmax still with us.
Neil, today's about prices, Thursday's about spending.
Let's talk about retail sales.
How do you expect some of our understanding of prices this morning to show up in spending and retail sales later this week?
Well, I mean, if goods prices are rising and the consensus expects nominal, nominal retail sales to rise 3/10, that basically tells you that real spending on goods is declining.
That's not exactly an encouraging situation.
So um


You know, I mean, the fact that price increases are showing up, um, and you know, it's more or less matching what you see in the retail sales data, um, that basically tells you that the volume of goods sold is going down.
Look, it comes back to P * Q.
Whatever, um, you know, whatever goes into price is going to come out of quantity because the nominal anchor hasn't really changed.
Uh, so you know, look, I mean, I think consumers are actually quite resistant to higher prices, uh, with the exception of the uh, University of Michigan data.
Um, if you look at, you know, other estimates for inflation expectations, was whether that's the the New York Fed survey of consumer expectations, Atlanta Fed business inflation expectations, professional forecasters inflation expectations.
Um, it suggests that, you know, people are resistant to higher prices and they're acting as if, you know, if you look at the areas where people have been cutting back their consumption, those are the areas where the prices have been going up the most.
So it's not particularly surprising.
Um, and the labor markets remain still in a tricky spot.
Um, you know, while the unemployment rate remains low, uh, you still have, you know, rising increase in, you know, discouraged workers.
You know, people that are out of the workforce but want a job now.
Um, you know, companies are telling you like the small businesses are saying that there's uh, you know, poor sales, uh, a bigger concern.
So, you know, I I think that that probably reinforces ongoing weakness in uh, in wage growth, and you know, that means that households don't really have the capacity to absorb um, higher prices and that means to cut back.
No, and it's a good point, Neil.
And David, I guess that if you take what Neil is saying, the idea that you do see real price resistance by consumers, and if you do see this sort of compensating for the extra expense in goods by pulling back on services, what would the harm be for the Fed to cut rates by just 25 basis points or 50 basis points?
Well, the any, you know, any problems the economy is facing is not really about interest rates being too high.
And I think that I think, you know, I think we have to think carefully about long-term policies about helping the labor force grow, uh, about helping free enterprise and reduce regulation and reduce barriers to to business and and, you know, I think we need to focus on that.
Um, I don't think the interest rates are too high right now.
I think the Fed's the steward of the dollar and of our inflation outlook in the long run.
And they've said they're committed to 2% inflation.
I think they should stick to their guns.
Um, and you know, if the economy gets into trouble, it's not because they kept rates too high.
Neil, I just want to give you the final word just on housing, which is something you've been following now for months and months and months and flagging the weakness here.
Why is that so important to you, Neil?
Well, because it undercuts an argument that was just made, which is that, you know, that interest rates are fine, right?
I mean, obviously housing isn't weakening because of tariffs or anything else.
Housing's weakening because rates are too high and you're seeing um, you know, a rising pile of completed new unsold inventory.
I mean that hasn't been as high, uh, that's that's been rising, um, you know, over the last year or so and that's starting to weigh on home prices which we see.
So you know, I I think that the housing market does provide some evidence that interest rates are restraining economic activity.
Is that the Fed's fault or is that the fault of Congress, Neil?
So no, but the reason the reason we're seeing that, sorry, the re reason uh, the reason we're have got trouble in the housing market is not because rates are too high now.
It's because rates were way too low for way too long after the great financial crisis causing prices to jack up to a level that cannot be supported at normal mortgage rates.
There's nothing wrong with mortgage rates.
The problem is home prices which are too high because rates were too low for too long.
Well, mortgage rates are running 6 and 1/2 to 7% and wage growth is rising just 3%.
So, I think the math is actually getting quite challenging for most people.
That's why housing is not working.
Well, it's challenging, but only because home prices are the anomaly here.
They're just too high because rates were too low for too long.
I'm sitting back now, Jent.
I thought you'd continue.
Neil D of Remma, David Kelly at JP Morgan.
